data.title: MCT serves a nostalgic look at newlyweds with 'Barefoot in the Park'
data.meta_description: MCT opens its season with Neil Simon's romantic comedy \
data.text:

The works of Neil Simon, once a staple on Broadway and at local theaters, are no longer as easy to find. And that is a shame, for they overflow with humor and are spot-on about the hilarious vagaries of urban life. Yes, they are products of a specific era, and as such are now vintage, but charmingly so.

Melbourne Civic Theatre’s Peg Girard, a director who follows her own drummer, selected a Simon period piece to lift the spirits of her audiences this summer. Girard knows her Simon, since the first play she directed for MCT was “I Ought to be in Pictures.” Last year she presented pandemic-tired audiences with “The Prisoner of Second Avenue,” a very identifiable Simon character, given the times.

“I don’t pay much attention to whatever is trendy among other community theaters nationwide, but Mr. Simon’s plays have been consistently popular with MCT’s audiences throughout my entire tenure,” said Girard.

“He may have suffered some backlash late in his career from those resentful of his popularity, but since his passing has been re-embraced in the odd American custom of revering artists by virtue of their being dead.”

“Barefoot in the Park” premiered on Broadway in 1963. Directed by the legendary Mike Nichols, the play starred Elizabeth Ashley and Robert Redford in his pre-Sundance Kid days. An instant success, “Barefoot” ran for 1,530 performances, making it Simon’s longest-running play and the tenth longest-running non-musical in Broadway history.

“Barefoot is one of his (Simon’s) earliest success, and showcases the traits for which he would become famous---the one-liners, the family conflict, the New York sensibility,” explained Girard.

The MCT production is faithful to Simon’s original story line of Corie and Paul, a proto-Dharma and Greg, as they maneuver married life in their New York walk-up. Flower child Corie believes everything will work out fine, while uptight Paul is not so sure, but would love to be able to let his hair down and walk “barefoot in the park.”

MCT’s refreshing version of the classic stars Mary Carson Barnette as Corie and Anthony DeTrano as Paul, with support from Victoria Smith as Ethel Banks, Dana Blanchard as Victor Velasco and Anthony Santiago as Harry Pepper, the phone repairman.

The charms of “Barefoot in the Park” lie in its lack of pretense of being anything other than a romantic comedy about two very different individuals trying to make a go of it as a couple. Its nostalgic glow about what love and marriage was all about in the early 1960s - before the sexual revolution - is also endearingly dated.

For folks of a certain age, “Barefoot in the Park” basks in the warm glow of memory. For a younger crowd, it’s a whole new ballgame.

“There are whole generations who have no history with it,” said Girard. “They are discovering it for the first time.”

If you go

'Barefoot in the Park'

Where: Melbourne Civic Theatre, 817 E. Strawbridge Ave., Melbourne

When: 8 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays and 2 p.m. Sundays through Sept. 12. There is an added matinee at 2 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 28, with no evening show on that day.

Tickets: $30

Info: 321-723-6935

On the web: mymct.org

Fun facts about 'Barefoot in the Park'

Myrna Loy was in the national tour and Dorothy Lamour played Mrs. Banks in the dinner theater circuit.

Robert Redford reprised his character in the 1967 film, this time alongside Jane Fonda.

Marvelous mother figure Mildred Natwick was in both the Broadway and film versions.

A television series based on the premise starred Scoey Mitchell and Tracy Reed as a newly married African-American couple.
